children.subject: For SWE 161 and 168 will be by far more applicable than 126 and 127. Between 161 and 168, 161 will give you a more "full stack" view since security touches upon every aspect of software engineering. 126 and 127 are definitely great classes to take but will be more mathematical and geared towards machine learning.

Thanks for the explanations, it doesn't seem CS 168 fits my goals.

I'm not particularly interested in networking, so should I still take 161? Is learning security helpful or necessary as a SWE?

I have not taken 170 yet; would you recommend me to do so instead of CS 168?

I do plan to take 189. Pretty much my question is: which two classes of 168, 161, 170, 126, and 127 should I take with the least redundancies and most applications? I want my CS classes to specifically prepare me as a SWE, but if not all do, I would only choose the classes that do and use the remaining spaces for statistics/ML.

To clarify, networking is one of the things that 161 goes over. It goes over security in a lot of other areas as well, but the amount of networking it goes over is good enough in practice. 

But at a lot of companies there will be dedicated people working on security so I would say if you are not interested in working in security, 161 would be helpful but not necessary. 

Since it seems you are interested in ML you should take 170, 126, and 127. I know that is three of the courses and not two but for your purposes I would prioritize these over 186 since you plan to take 162.

With 162, 170, 126, and 127 you will get a nice breadth of material and good foundations. With 162 and 170 you will be able to pick up a lot of systems concepts from 161, 168, and 186 on your own if needed, and it gives you more time to take courses in ML/statistics.
Another person interested in systems. After 162, I would highly recommend taking 164. You work on involved projects in teams where you build the stages of a compiler.

I'll provide a different perspective as a person interested in systems instead of ML. I would prioritize the listed classes in the following way: 162, 186, 161, 126/127, 168.

168 focuses more on the design decisions used in the internet instead of a true software engineering class (like 61B or 162). If you have taken 170 then you can easily teach yourself every algorithm used in 168 (except maybe TCP, but they go over that in 162). As for the software engineering side of networking, 161 provides a practical approach instead of the theoretical approach of 168.

history.content: For system building, 161 and 168 are certainly relevant. For lots of roles, 126 and 127 are very relevant. It's hard to predict what you'll need in your career, but I think either path is very reasonable preparation for future careers.
I've heard that CS 162 and CS 186 help when working in the industry, but how useful is CS 161 and CS 168 for SWE? Can I take EECS 126 and EECS 127 instead to broaden my skillset?
history.subject: Course Recommendations?
